Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: New Chemical Methods Enabled by Visible Light Photocatalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this CAREER award, the Chemical Synthesis program is supporting the integrated research and education program of Professor Corey Stephenson of the University of Michigan. This research aims to develop green chemical methodologies mediated by visible light sensitization. The methodologies will benefit both laboratory and industrial research by introducing a more efficient, environmentally benign approach for producing biologically active materials for further investigations. This research will also play an important role in the PI's educational plans, both as a training opportunity for students in his laboratory, and also a hands-on experimental module designed to engage high school students in the excitement of interdisciplinary science. Dr. Stephenson reaches out to high school students by participating in the Wolverine Express (an annual statewide high school visitation program) and developing a High School Chemistry Week Program and a course for the Michigan Math and Science Scholars Program.

This research investigates operationally simple, catalytic methods that forgo the need for specialized photochemistry equipment, utilizing inexpensive household light bulbs and energy efficient LEDs for irradiation. It aims to develop 1) a general, catalytic approach to radical chemistry taking advantage of ligand dependent redox properties of ruthenium and iridium polypyridine complexes; and 2) a catalytic approach to the activation of carbon-oxygen bond towards nucleophilic displacement reactions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. This grant focused on the use of visible light photoredox catalysis for generation of reactive chemical species, typically organic free radicals, for the construction of new complex molecules. Traditionally these highly valuable reactive intermediates were generated using harsh conditions with the addition of toxic or difficult to handle reagents. In this grant cycle, we established the viability of visible light as a mild and environmentally benign mechanism to generate these species and control their concomitant reactivity. Specifically, reduction of alkyl, alkenyl and aryl bromides and iodides has been achieved and coupled with subsequent C-C bond forming events. Atom transfer radical addition has also been achieved by rationally changing catalysts to direct the mechanistic pathway. Catalytic carbon-oxygen bond activation was discovered via in situ generation of the Vilsmeier–Haack reagent upon irradiation in the presence of a photocatalyst, CBr4 and DMF, providing a catalytic alternative to stoichiometric reactions such as the Appel or Mitsunobu.

As measured by productivity, the impact of this funding can be seen in the publications and presentations that have arisen during the granting period to disseminate the results to the broader community.

16 peer-reviewed publications with >1000 total citations

>30 presentations and posters given by undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows at local, regional and national meetings

Training opportunities for >15 undergraduate and graduate students, and postdoctoral fellows have been facilitated byt his research funding

Broader Impacts. The utility of free radicals for chemical synthesis has not been fully realized as a consequence of the means by which they are traditionally generated, and the environmental impact of the byproducts of their formation. Visible light photocatalysis has helped to reinvigorate research into mild and environmentally benign approaches to access these versatile species.

The University of Michigan is a state university dedicated to educating, ground-breaking scientific research, and outreach at both the undergraduate and graduate levels. Importantly, Michigan is an underrepresented serving institution that promotes diversity in all education areas. As part of this NSF Career award, we have undertaken two major efforts in this regard.

Michigan Math and Science Scholars Program (MMSS). We have organized and supervised the Michigan Math Science Scholars course on Green Chemistry, Catalysis and Solar Energy Conversion. These courses last for two weeks (two sessions each summer with ~30 students) and are aimed at introducing a diverse set of high school students to advanced concepts in catalysis with an emphasis on sustainable chemistry. This educational program requires each of the graduate students in the group to design an experiment adhering to the course's goal of Green Chemistry, Catalysis, and Solar Energy; preparing a written step-by-step laboratory procedure for the students; supervising and teaching the students for a day-long session; and finally to encourage students to actively participate in hands-on activities and field-trips to Cayman Chemical, Dow Chemical, and a local botanical garden where the students learned about chemicals in nature. The ultimate goal for this program is to encourage high school students of various backgrounds to become excited about the STEM fields.

Females Excelling in More in Math, Engineering and the Sciences (FEMMES). The FEMMES program offers the opportunity for research groups at the university, across multiple scientific disciplines, to design and lead activities that educate local elementary school-level girls about each group's respective research fields.  Every semester, graduate students in our group organize a day of fun, chemistry-focused demonstrations and activities (e.g. making liquid nitrogen ice cream) for the goal of introducing elementary school-level girls to basic chemistry concepts in an exciting, hands-on manner.  Through our participation in the FEMMES program, we hope to actively reach out to young girls in the community to help them foster an interest in chemistry, as well as develop greater knowledge and confidence in learning about STEM fields.
